Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effects of Preoperative Midazolam on Postoperative Sleep in Children

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either preoperative acetaminophen only (control group, n = 32) or both acetaminophen and midazolam (experimental group, n = 38).

Participants.evidence: Conducted at Yale-New Haven Childrenâ€™s Hospital, this two-group randomised controlled trial included 70 children aged 3 to 12 years.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either preoperative acetaminophen only (control group, n = 32) or both acetaminophen and midazolam (experimental group, n = 38).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of preoperative midazolam on postoperative sleep in children undergoing ambulatory tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative sleep, evaluated using actigraphy over a specified timeframe.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either preoperative acetaminophen only (control group, n = 32) or both acetaminophen and midazolam (experimental group, n = 38).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on all randomised participants using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Children in the midazolam group experienced significantly fewer nighttime awakenings compared to the control group (p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group, indicating the safety of midazolam in this context.
